content.text:
I need to analyze this claim carefully before querying the database.

**Reading the claim:** "If the youngest patient who underwent any recorded medical examination in the database had presented without any neurologic complaints, the diagnosis would have been postponed by six months."

This is a **counterfactual** claim. It uses the structure "If [patient] had presented without [X], [Y] would have happened." It describes a hypothetical scenario — what would have occurred if circumstances had been different from what actually happened.

A database records what actually happened, not what would have happened under hypothetical changes. There is no way to verify from the data whether a diagnosis "would have been postponed by six months" in an alternate scenario.

According to my classification rules, counterfactual claims should **always** be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

```json
{"label": "NOT ENOUGH INFO", "reasoning": "This is a counterfactual claim. It uses hypothetical language ('If the youngest patient...had presented without...the diagnosis would have been postponed by six months'), describing an imagined scenario about what would have happened under different circumstances. A database only records what actually happened, not what would have occurred under hypothetical changes. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from database data."}
```
